------=_NextPart_000_0ED1_01C303A5.97547E50
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Gordon,

We can have our call as suggested on Wednesday 8:30p PT (3:30UTC).=


The test sources used are checked into CVS. Look for the packages 
- test=
.javanio.http - Contains the Async and Sync http downloader implementation =
written to benchmark the java nio apis.
- test.sedanio.http - Contains the =
SEDA aSocket based http downloader ( exactly similar to its javanio counter=
part).

As you said, the maxConnections is not a strict target; so the actu=
al number of connections at any point could be less than it; but not more.
=

We had earlier raised the value of maxClients parameter suitably in httpd.=
conf to allow apache to service more than the default 150 clients simultane=
ously.

Today we found that the sandstorm script by default ships with ( -m=
s128M -mx1024M ) options. This setting results in GC getting called very la=
tely but when called, it takes about a minute to complete. This is the reas=
on behind the previous test results showing very less throughput above 100 =
simulataneous connections. After removing it, we see the following throughp=
ut.

100 connections - about 4.0 Mbytes/sec ( This is same as the reading w=
e got before )
250 connections - about 2.7 Mbytes/sec ( This was less than =
1 Mbytes/sec before )
500 connections - about 1.8 Mbytes/sec ( This was les=
s than 1 Mbytes/sec before )

which means that the throughput indeed degrad=
es with the number of connections; but not as bad as before.

We also ran a=
nother quick test wherein we used NBIO instead of the java NIO. We noticed =
that the throughput degraded to 1.8 Mbytes/sec in the 100 connections case.=
 This makes things even more fishy.

The differences between our setup and =
the setup used by the SEDA benchmarks are

Crawler Setup                   =
 -- SEDA benchmark Setup

- Sun JDK 1.4.1                 -- IBM JDK 1.1.8
=
- JDK 1.4 NIO library          -- NBIO library
- 100 Mbps Ethernet         =
 -- Gigabit Ethernet
- No Cache on Webserver  -- Must have had caching.
 
T=
he other test combinations we are running now over our SEDA Http downloader=
 are
- Try java -server option.
- Try JDK 1.4.2 beta.
- Try IBM JDK 1.4
- T=
ry IBM JDK 1.1.8 with NBIO - This is the closest comparison that we can do =
against SEDA benchmarks.
- Do tests enabling the web server cache.


Thanks=
,
Reddy

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Gordon Mohr 
  To: archive=
-crawler@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Tuesday, April 15, 2003 12:33 AM
  Subjec=
t: Re: [archive-crawler] SEDA Performance !!


  Thanks for the updated ana=
lysis!

  However, I am concerned that the results may be more a result of =
the
  test design or the specific HTTP implementation we're using than the
=
  underlying NIO/aSocket code, because the results diverge so greatly
  fro=
m SEDA's own published performance testing.

  For example, the results at.=
..

    http://www.cs.berkeley.edu/~mdw/proj/sandstorm/iocore-bench/index.h=
tml

  ...show strong throughput up through 1,000 simultaneous connections,=

  indeed even up past 10,000 simultaneous connections.

  Also, given the =
note about the 1.4.1 -> 1.4.2 JRE NIO change, a test
  under 1.4.2 is neces=
sary to truly evaluate either of the asynchronous
  options.

  Some other =
questions about the test setup:

  - the meaning of "maxConnections" is unc=
lear to me; it seems it
     is not a "maximum" but a "target", and the act=
ual number of
     connections at any point in time might be larger or smal=
ler.
     Is this right?

  - do you have any other intrumentation which su=
ggests it is
     specifically garbage collection which is causing the degr=
adation
     of the SEDA approach above 100 connections?

  - if some of th=
e setups are hitting garbage-collection or other
     resource thresholds, =
more info about the test machine/VM would
     be helpful: RAM, VM options =
used (server hotspot? heap/stack
     sizes? etc.)

  - with only 2 Apache =
web servers to one client process, we may
     be testing/hitting Apache pe=
rformance limits as much as Java/IO
     limits. For example, default Apach=
e will only accept 150 simultaneous
     clients; by my reading of the test=
 setup this means that no
     matter how many connections the LAN test att=
empted, it would
     never succeed on more than 300 (across the two test A=
paches)
     at once -- so any LAN test numbers over 300 aren't really
    =
 indicative of Java performance.

  - is the test code something you could =
check into CVS?

  These figures are all very interesting, and even if quir=
ks in
  the test are pushing results one way or the other, that will
  usua=
lly generate useful info, too.

  - Gordon

  ----- Original Message -----
=
  From: G.B.Reddy
  To: archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com
  Sent: Friday, Apr=
il 11, 2003 3:16 PM
  Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] SEDA Performance !!


=
  Gordon,

  Please find attached the performance report on the SEDA aSocke=
t NIO layer. Look for the last section in the document "SEDA NIO
  Socket F=
ramework" and the "Summary" section is also updated with the results. An ex=
cel sheet with the readings and the graph is also
  attached for reference.=


  We would like to have a brief chat with you on Tuesday 8:30 pm PST ( Mo=
nday is a holiday for us on the eve of Tamil new year ) about
  SEDA socket=
 layer and generally about the various tasks and other proceedings.

  JAnt=
 Build Status :

  - The proposed directory structure is not yet created si=
nce we are still in the Anecdote prototyping stage and we do not have any
 =
 complete package to checkin. I have modified the ant script a bit to suit =
the present Anecdote structure and activated a cronjob
  over it. I have al=
so added you and Raymie to the notification mail-ids list so that you would=
 also get the nightly build mails. You
  could get the nightly build from t=
he location "/home/users/w/wc/wcr-team/NightlyBuilds" as stated in the mail=
 on
  shell.sourceforge.net. You could use your own logins and do SFTP to a=
ccess the NightlyBuilds directory. It has read permissions for
  all.

  - =
I am not sure why the stata labs libraries ( st.ata.* packages) have been c=
hecked in as a separate CVS module. Are we planning to
  upgrade/modify tho=
se sources and maintain ourselves. If not, we could just have the built cla=
sses in a jar in CVS lib directory as
  we had done for other third party l=
ibraries. Otherwise, if we want to maintain it, then would we require that =
to be a separate CVS
  module ? I think it would be better if we have one C=
VS root module under which everything is put in. Probably, in such cases, w=
e can
  have a "thiryPartySrc" directory to maintain such sources within ou=
r main module "OpenWebCrawler" itself.

  Thanks,
  Reddy


  ----- Origina=
l Message -----
  From: G.B.Reddy
  To: archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com
  S=
ent: Friday, April 11, 2003 12:46 AM
  Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Statu=
s !!


  Gordon,

  As you say, the aSocketInputStream is needed only if th=
e client stage is multithreaded. But the oceanstore "HttpClient" stage is
 =
 internally using it to do sequencing which is unnecessary since anyway the=
 "HttpClient" class implements
  SingleThreadedEventHandlerIF. I have remov=
ed these overheads to do my performance testing.

  After starting to test =
the SEDA socket performance, I ran into three problems in the SEDA's socket=
 framework.

  - Newly discovered bug : The seda internals throw Concurrent=
Modification exceptions when iterating through the selector's registered
  =
keys. This exceptions is highly reproducible when more number of concurrent=
 downloads happen. Synchronization has not been taken
  care when the ReadE=
ventHandler tries to deregister the socket from the selector of the WriteEv=
entHandler. ( As you would know, there
  are three stages ReadStage, WriteS=
tage and ListenStage in the seda socket framework. Each has its own java Se=
lector instance and
  they wait on its select call. The ReadStage is the on=
e that determines that a connection is terminated. When this happens, it
  =
directly tries to make a deregister call on the WriteStage's selector on th=
is socket object. So, easily concurrent mod exceptions
  are thrown when my=
 downloader stage is pumping requests and making new connections). I shall =
raise this bug to the author and I am
  proceeding with my fix on it. Becau=
se of this unsynchronized communication, a lot of CancelledKeyExceptions ar=
e also thrown in the
  internals.

  - A documented bug : ConcurrentModific=
ation exceptions when iterating through the selector's selectedKeys. This i=
s also due to no
  synchronization. Multiple threads are allowed by the sed=
a internals to do select calls on a single selector. (Look for the docs in
=
  seda.sandStorm.lib.aSocket.nio.NIOSelectSource.doPoll method). I will hav=
e to look for doing some minimal synchronization as stated
  in there.

  -=
 There has been other rare NullPointerExceptions and IllegalArgumentExcepti=
on in some places. I will have to look into their
  implications.

  I will=
 fix the last two problems and get the performance measurements tomorrow.

=
  Thanks,
  Reddy

  ----- Original Message -----
  From: Gordon Mohr
  To:=
 archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com
  Sent: Wednesday, April 09, 2003 12:17 AM=

  Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Status !!


  Thanks for the update!

  T=
he Ocenstore libhttp package is known to be very rough; really just a
  pla=
ceholder or starting point for what we'd need. (Note that there's
  also an=
 alternative 'libhttp2' package in OceanStore, but it seemed both
  unused =
in their other code and more elaborate, so I haven't tried
  to use it yet.=
)

  The TCP response ordering capabilities to aSocketInputStream only seem=

  necessary if you have multiple threads reading from the same socket -- w=
hich
  I think can, and probably should, be avoided.

  I'm looking forward=
 to seeing the test results.

  I like the BuildDesign proposal; please mov=
e forward with creating
  that structure for a new module on the sourceforg=
e CVS. However,
  please use the module name of "ArchiveOpenCrawler" (inste=
ad of
  "Web-crawler").

  Thanks!

  - Gordon

  ----- Original Message --=
---
  From: G.B.Reddy
  To: archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com
  Sent: Tuesday=
, April 08, 2003 11:04 AM
  Subject: [archive-crawler] Status !!


  Gordon=
,

  I am presently working on the SEDA socket overhead determination work.=
 I will get the results in the next two days. Some initial
  insights into =
it are
  - Oceanstore manages both Tx and Rx in a single stage.
  - It just=
 holds the responses in memory only. It does not write into tmp files if th=
ey are huge.
  - TCP response reordering is done by using the seda.sandStor=
m.lib.aSocket.aSocketInputStream class which reorders packets according
  t=
o the ATcpInPacket sequence number.

  The test that will be done :
  - Por=
t the downloader code ( which we had written earlier during the java nio pe=
rformance tests ) to SEDA framework and use the
  OceanStore library for HT=
TP fetching. The same tests that we did for the downloader will be repeated=
 in this oceanstore setup. We
  are removing some oceanstore code to make i=
t similar. The result of this test would tell us the percentage of overhead=
 imposed by
  the SEDA framework.


  We are also done with the JAnt packag=
ing scripts. It uses the present CVS structure itself. I shall create the p=
roposed CVS
  structure after you approve it. Today we have put the cronjob=
 for testing the web hosting part of nightly builds. We shall enable it
  f=
or all tomorrow. As of now, only the last nightly build will be available f=
or download. More changes need to be made for hosting
  every nightly build=
 of a week.

  Thanks,
  Reddy

is group, send an email to:

  ADVERTISEMENT




  To unsubscribe from this grou=
p, send an email to:
  archive-crawler-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com

r use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.

: G.B.Reddy<BR>To: archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com<BR>Sent:

l 11, 2003 12:46 AM<BR>Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Status 
  !!<BR><BR><=
BR>Gordon,<BR><BR>As you say, the aSocketInputStream is needed only 
  if t=
he client stage is multithreaded. But the oceanstore "HttpClient" stage 
  =
is<BR>internally using it to do sequencing which is unnecessary since anywa=
y 
  the "HttpClient" class implements<BR>SingleThreadedEventHandlerIF. I h=
ave 
  removed these overheads to do my performance testing.<BR><BR>After s=
tarting to 
  test the SEDA socket performance, I ran into three problems i=
n the SEDA's 
  socket framework.<BR><BR>- Newly discovered bug : The seda =
internals throw 
  ConcurrentModification exceptions when iterating through=
 the selector's 
  registered<BR>keys. This exceptions is highly reproducib=
le when more number of 
  concurrent downloads happen. Synchronization has =
not been taken<BR>care when 
  the ReadEventHandler tries to deregister the=
 socket from the selector of the 
  WriteEventHandler. ( As you would know,=
 there<BR>are three stages ReadStage, 
  WriteStage and ListenStage in the =
seda socket framework. Each has its own java 
  Selector instance and<BR>th=
ey wait on its select call. The ReadStage is the 
  one that determines tha=
t a connection is terminated. When this happens, 
  it<BR>directly tries to=
 make a deregister call on the WriteStage's selector on 
  this socket obje=
ct. So, easily concurrent mod exceptions<BR>are thrown when my 
  downloade=
r stage is pumping requests and making new connections). I shall 
  raise t=
his bug to the author and I am<BR>proceeding with my fix on it. Because 
  =
of this unsynchronized communication, a lot of CancelledKeyExceptions are a=
lso 
  thrown in the<BR>internals.<BR><BR>- A documented bug : ConcurrentMo=
dification 
  exceptions when iterating through the selector's selectedKeys=
. This is also 
  due to no<BR>synchronization. Multiple threads are allowe=
d by the seda 
  internals to do select calls on a single selector. (Look f=
or the docs 
  in<BR>seda.sandStorm.lib.aSocket.nio.NIOSelectSource.doPoll =
method). I will 
  have to look for doing some minimal synchronization as s=
tated<BR>in 
  there.<BR><BR>- There has been other rare NullPointerExcepti=
ons and 
  IllegalArgumentException in some places. I will have to look int=
o 
  their<BR>implications.<BR><BR>I will fix the last two problems and get=
 the 
  performance measurements tomorrow.<BR><BR>Thanks,<BR>Reddy<BR><BR>-=

R><BR><BR>Gordon,<BR><BR>I am 
  presently working on the SEDA socket overh=
ead determination work. I will get 
  the results in the next two days. Som=
e initial<BR>insights into it are<BR>- 
  Oceanstore manages both Tx and Rx=
 in a single stage.<BR>- It just holds the 
  responses in memory only. It =
does not write into tmp files if they are 
  huge.<BR>- TCP response reorde=
ring is done by using the 
  seda.sandStorm.lib.aSocket.aSocketInputStream =
class which reorders packets 
  according<BR>to the ATcpInPacket sequence n=
umber.<BR><BR>The test that will be 
  done :<BR>- Port the downloader code=
 ( which we had written earlier during the 
  java nio performance tests ) =
to SEDA framework and use the<BR>OceanStore 
  library for HTTP fetching. T=
he same tests that we did for the downloader will 
  be repeated in this oc=
eanstore setup. We<BR>are removing some oceanstore code 
  to make it simil=
ar. The result of this test would tell us the percentage of 
  overhead imp=
osed by<BR>the SEDA framework.<BR><BR><BR>We are also done with 
  the JAnt=

eate the proposed CVS<BR>structure after you approve it. Today we have put =
